Fair enough the special effects are brilliant but that's the only good thing you can say.  I went to see this at the cinema with my friend and we both walked out which I have always said I would never do.  Very, very bad film which you don't care what the outcome is.  YAAAWWNNN!!!!

The Nutty Professor 2: The Klumps (2000): Dir: Peter Segal / Cast: Eddie Murphy, Janet Jackson, Larry Miller, John Ales, Wanda Sykes: Sequel with ideas and innovation that, despite its efforts, never involves viewers. It regards unity or family starring Eddie Murphy who returns as professor Sherman Klump. Janet Jackson is introduced as his fiancé but a gene of egotistical Buddy Love still exists thus preventing Sherman from having total control. Plot regards a youth formula that Buddy wishes to obtain. They have tested it successfully on a dog but a hair drifts into it thus leaving Buddy contracting symptoms. Excellent makeup with a giant hamster poising an attack against police. Directed by Peter Segal who has directed comedy sequels before with the hilarious The Naked Gun 33 1/3: The Final Insult. Murphy carries the film conveying Sherman and Buddy on screen at once. He also portrays members of the Klump family but the youthful finale lacks emotional payoff. Jackson is no Jada Pinkett. In fact, one could guess that Pinkett suspected that this would not live up to the first film. Larry Miller and John Ales reprise their roles as dean and student associate but they are merely appearances. Special effects are creative and inventive but the youth formula needs explanation that prevents this film from becoming involving and merely settling for big budget chaos. Score: 4 ½ / 10

Sherman Klump is getting married, and the family could not be more delighted for him. But Buddy Love, his alter-ego, is back and trying to make it on his own. Buddy keeps resurfacing in untimely outbursts, and threatening the professor's marriage plans to Denise. Utilising Denise's cutting edge DNA research, Sherman decides to rid himself of his nemesis, and his outbursts once and for all by extracting Buddy's DNA from his system. But Buddy bursts full bodied into Sherman's world and lays claim to the professor's invention, a revolutionary youth serum. Desperate to keep it from Buddy, Sherman hides the serum in the Klump family home, thinking it will be safe. But to get it, Buddy has to deal with the entire Klump family first....The first film was a return to form for Murphy, he put everything he had into that movie, and it was one of the most heartwarming movies of Murphys career.This in the other hand, is the Buddy Love to that movie. It's loud, crass, really over the top with the innuendo, and worst of all devoid of any laughs.I was looking forward to the family having dinner scene, but it was basically the same as the first, and everything that you liked about Sherman was taken away, thanks to his little outbursts every now and again.The first film had a great script and story, but this relies heavily on gross out humour and disgusting set pieces.This was the beginning of Murphys second decline, almost ten years after his first, and apart from Shrek, he still has to recover.It's his worst movie by miles, and i've seen Best Defence.

reviews.review_title: The writing and concepts felt rushed and not as funny or entertaining as the previous picture
reviews.content: Nutty Professor II: The Klumps (2000) is a movie in the DVD collection that I recently rewatched with my daughter on Netflix. The storyline for this follows our favorite professor as he tries to move on from the events of the last movie while dealing with the insecurities of his weight and his previous happiness as Buddy Love. He meets a new love interest and as things get serious he realizes that he still has side effects from the previous use of his product. Meanwhile out of nowhere Buddy has returned as a separate entity than Professor Klump further complicating matters. This movie is directed by Peter Segal (Naked Gun 33 1/3) and stars Eddie Murphy (Golden Child), Janet Jackson (Poetic Justice), Larry Miller (Pretty Woman), Richard Gant (Jason Goes to Hell), Wanda Sykes (Bad Moms) and Chris Elliott (Scary Movie 2). The storyline for this picture was absolutely dreadful compared to the first one. The writing and concepts felt rushed and not as funny or entertaining as the previous picture. I will say the opening buffet scene, granny scenes and the proposal were funny; but other than that, most of the other scenes seemed awkward. Murphy was still outstanding in this and did the best he could; but honestly, there wasn't much to see here. This is a very average addition to the genre that I'd score a 4.5-5/10.

In 1996, a new kind of comedy was born. Using advanced, fake "fat," filmmakers turned Eddie Murphy into a blob named Sherman Klump, of the Klump family; a band of rude, crude, obnoxious and extremely large pigs.
 "The Nutty Professor 2: The Klumps," continues the story of Sherman Klump and his weight losing potion, which this time holds even "smaller" attributes in store for its consumer... I'll admit that the "fat" on Murphy is extremely convincing and repulsing, much like the Austin Powers character "Fat B*s*a*d." Unfortunately, much to the effort of the film crew on "The Klumps," this flop contains few laughs, and is more disgusting and repulsive than the all three "Powers" films combined (well, maybe not, but almost...) Eddie Murphy is losing his star status, and without Shrek, he might have already been in the gutter by now. But after making flops like "Showtime" (decent film, still a flop) and "I Spy," Murphy will probably be eager for "Shrek 2" to come out. "The Klumps" is a horrid film, that stinks a mile away. Only watch if it's on cable, and you were a fan of the original, which I wasn't particularly... 1/5 stars-John Ulmer

Eddie Murphy was excellent portraying the different characters; that's actually what made me pay the $8.50 to see this movie in the first place. But after this movie, hardly ever again will i go to the movie theater to watch a comedy again.  The story in this movie is simply horrible.  Eddie Murphy's talent holds this movie together with his acting of the Klumps; but the story suffers miserably.  Overall, it's a disappointing sequel.

The comedy genre doesn't appeal to me, however Eddie Murphy's impeccable, dynamic and diverse performance is simply passionate, you can't help but admire the formidable work done, a fun, simple and captivating comedy, a cute sequel, where. Alto They are the familiars of the protagonists, all with perfect performance by Murphy...

reviews.review_title: t was a bad movie, but it was fun to watch
reviews.content: It was a bad movie, but it was fun to watch. When I was a kid at my grandfather's house, I found the VHS and watched it.

reviews.review_title: Eddie Murphy tries his Best, but it wasn't enough,
reviews.content: Nutty Professor II: The Klumps is a brutal movie with a very poorly written storyline, despite a great comedic cast. Eddie Murphy is very good in this movie and it's still very entertaining to see him portray so many different characters that are nothing like the other, but sadly it just dosen't work out like the first one did, it isn't as funny, it was very rare that I genuinely laughed during this. The storyline is ridiculous, the first one was as well, but it embraced that fact, however, with this it almost seems to think it's clever, using different science formulas to create substances and inventions that would never work in real life, the way in which Buddy Love comes back is stupid, I know these movies don't aim to be scientifically accurate, but this was just pure stupidity. I could tolerate the films dumb, far fetched storyline if it was a good comedy, but it's not at all, every joke is lame and, for the most part, really disgusting, it seemed to rely on being gross, even hard to watch at times, instead of trying to be funny. Murphy is a talented comedian, but he's not enough to recommend Nutty Professor II: the Klumps, better off avoided. Sherman Klump's upcoming product launch and love life are threatened by the return of Buddy Love, the ruder and louder side of him. Best Performance: Eddie Murphy

Continuing my plan to watch every Eddie Murphy movie in order, I come to The Nutty Professor 2: The KlumpsPlot In A Paragraph: Buddy Love returns just as everything is going great for Sherman Klump.I didn't enjoy this at all. I loved the dinner table scene in the first movie, but a little goes a long way. It's too much here. The alleged humour is awfully unfunny. Ruder and cruder does not make it funnier. Considering how much I liked the first one, this, this is a huge disappointment.Nutty Professor 2 grossed $123 million at the domestic box office, to end the year the 16th highest grossing movie of the year.

reviews.review_title: Excellent, hilarious sequel about respecting yourself which is sometimes crass
reviews.content: NUTTY PROFESSOR II: THE KLUMPS, in my opinion, is an excellent, hilarious sequel about respecting yourself which is sometimes crass. If you ask me, Klump (Eddie Murphy) was a very brilliant scientist despite the fact that he sometimes let Buddy (Eddie Murphy) get the best of him. When Buddy started acting like a dog, I laughed like a hyena. Also, I thought that Leanne (Melinda McGraw) was kind of snobby. In addition, I thought that Denise (Janet Jackson) was a very beautiful woman. Also, when Cletus (Eddie Murphy) used Klump's formula, I laughed really hard. You'll have to see the film if you want to know why. Before I wrap this up, I'd like to say that everything about this film was spectacular, especially the performances. Now, in conclusion, I highly recommend this excellent, hilarious sequel about respecting yourself which is sometimes crass to any Eddie Murphy fan who hasn't seen it.

First we see a remake of the original then we see this.... garbage. This movie was...was...there is no word to explain the level of badness. When I saw this movie half the theater got up and left within five seconds of the movie. When will Eddie Murphy learn he is not funny anymore, making movies like this, Dr. Dolittle 2, and That Pluto Nash garbage. If anyone watched this movie and liked it please tell me because your stupid and I would like to make fun of you.Rating: Zero Thumbs Up

reviews.review_title: Entertaining enough sequel has some genuine laughs but it is quite a mess.
reviews.content: Professor Sherman Klump (Eddie Murphy) has finally found his dream woman, her name is Denise Gaines (Janet Jackson). Which she's also a professor as well. But Sherman still feels his alter-ego Buddy Love (Played by Murphy) is waiting to get the worse of him. Sherman is working on a new formula that is trying to find the answer of the fountain of love. But the formula only works in a limited time only and Sherman is trying to find the missing ingredient to his DNA Cutting Edge work. If he does, he will finally get the money he needs for his research. But when Sherman can't trouble his alter-ego Buddy anymore, he decides to destroy the genes in his body to get rid of Buddy by injecting himself. Now the rest of Buddy Love is in a liquid goo. By destroying Buddy, it seems to work but Sherman is slowly losing his brain cells and losing his intelligence. Now Buddy finds himself back in human form with that got accidentally mixed with Dog DNA! Now Buddy tries to the steal the formula by stalking Sherman and his overbearing family (Nearly all played by Murphy as well).Directed by Peter Segal (Naked Gun 33 1/3:The Final Insult, Anger Management, The Longest Yard "2005") made an amusing enough sequel to the surprise box office hit of the 1996 remake. Murphy is just as brilliant playing six various characters in the movie and the make-up effects by six times Oscar-Winner:Rick Baker (Click, Coming to America, Ed Wood) are just as wonderful to look at. But Segal's wild energy and the often funny if messy screenplay by Barry W. Blaustein (Beyond the Mat, The Ringer), David Sheffield (Police Academy 2:The First Assignment, Boomering, The Honeymooners), Paul Weitz (About a Boy, American Pie, Down to Earth) and Chris Weitz (Antz, The Golden Compass) doesn't always pay off.The direction is a mess at times and the script, especially the wild humour is not always on target. But there's some good genuine laughs here and a few gross-out humour as well. While this sequel is a bit different from the 1996 picture, it doesn't quite match the quality of the first movie. Although Jackson is actually more charming as his love interest than Jada Pinkett Smith did in the 1996 version. Die-Hard fans of Murphy's work and Baker's wonderful make-up effects will certainly find some amusing here. It is certainly not the worst or best of Murphy's work but it's entertaining and far from boring. Worth a look. From a story by Steve Oedekerk (Ace Ventura 2:When Nature Calls, Nothing to Lose, Patch Adams), Blaustein and Sheffield. Unrated Version also available. (*** ½/*****).

reviews.review_title: Genetic extraction at its most devious!
reviews.content: "Nutty Professor II: The Klumps" is a nutty, wacky, funny, touching sequel to the 1996 film "The Nutty Professor", starring Eddie Murphy times seven, portraying virtually the entire Klump family! The family sequences in the first film created such an impact with audiences that it was decided that the sequel would focus much more on the Klump clan, resulting in some rather astonishing trick photography. Once again, the main character is the overweight, adorable, sweet-natured, brilliant genetics professor Sherman Klump, only this time around, his love interest is his colleague Prof. Denise Gaines (Janet Jackson). Reprising their roles from the first film are John Ales as Sherman's faithful student Jason, and Larry Miller as the pompous weenie Dean Richmond. The plot? Well, you'll just have to see it for yourselves.My favorite scenes from "The Klumps" include the following (DO NOT read any further if you have not yet seen this sequel). As Sherman rests by the fountain, Denise shows her deep love and concern for him when, upon discovering that he has lost almost all of his intelligence, she weeps and hugs him, promising that she will take care of him. When Sherman imagines himself as an astronaut, Papa Klump appears as Obi Wan Kanobe (spoofing "Star Wars") and instructs Sherman to use a "force" deep down inside him; Sherman does so by - what else? - farting! (I'm a sucker for toilet humor!) Grandma Klump really gets to shine in this movie as she gets horny with Sherman's arrogant alter ego Buddy Love. When Buddy accidentally drinks Sherman's youth formula and turns himself into goo, he winds up on a portly woman's butt and makes a wisecrack; the woman then turns around and slugs the guy behind her! Sherman tries to give his dad the Heimlich at a restaurant, causing Papa to fart and subsequently extinguish some nearby birthday candles, setting some curtains on fire. Sherman hires a Mariachi ensemble to serenade Denise on her balcony, but the presence of the evil Buddy inside the kindly Sherman (taking control of Sherman's thoughts and words) causes him to say and do certain things that abruptly end the serenade."Nutty Professor II: The Klumps" is a brilliantly entertaining comedy directed by Peter Segal. I must admit that I watched this sequel before I had even seen the first film, and as a result, it was a bit overwhelming. Funnier than the first movie? I don't know. When watching this film, or ANY film, I always try to separate the character from the actor; in this case, I'm not sure how I personally feel about Eddie Murphy and Janet Jackson, but I highly admire Sherman Klump and Denise Gaines for their brilliance, decency, and sweetness. On a final note, Murphy is to be commended for his skills as a character actor in this film, portraying several men and women of various heights, postures, walks, voices, personalities, etc.

I'm sorry to see many IMDb-users have not thought much of this excellent movie but then again, it's quite useless to argue what is funny and what is not. I just watched NP2 a second time and laughed my skinny ass off. Eddie's performance is CLASSIC and you totally forget that he's actually playing all of the family members. They're not Eddie anymore, they're the Klumps. I usually do not watch the "How this movie was made"-kind of extras, but this time I found myself making and exception and watching it made me appreciate Eddie's work even more. I knew it must've been difficultíssimo setting up those dinner scenes, but sheeeesh! Great work! There are too many classic moments in this film to mention....OK, I'll mention one: When the serum has reduced Buddy to a blob but still keeps on giving the passers-by hell. "What the HELL are you looking at!?!?" I hope they make a third one though I doubt it. Here's to yo fat ass, Sherman!

reviews.review_title: And this is WHOSE idea of a family movie?
reviews.content: "Nutty Professor II: The Klumps" has most of the same virtues of the previous movie and all of its vices, with Eddie Murphy again on form as Professor Klump, his family, and his alter ego Buddy Love; there are also some genuinely funny and tender moments. But alas, the movie is again undercut by its crudity; for every warm scene, writers Barry W. Blaustein, David Sheffield, Chris Weitz and Paul Weitz add about three or four jokes about bodily functions, sex etc. which all but cancel out the movie's points about people having to be what they are for better or worse (a message which nonetheless somehow manages to come through in the end).Sweet though she is, Janet Jackson proves that she was the peak of her powers, acting-wise, when she was on "Good Times" (the only time she registers is singing) - Nikki Cox's cameo as a student is more adept than Janet's entire performance. And there is no way on Earth the movie's low point - the scene with the giant hamster, an "inspired" mix of bestiality and, let's face it, rape - would EVER have been included in the final cut had the victim been a woman (see also a not dissimilar joke in "The Simpsons" with Homer and a panda).As for the Klumps, they were an entertaining side joke in the previous film, but upgrading them for the sequel was a mistake, especially since only Mama and Papa Klump really have anything worthwhile to do; would you want your daughter (or son, or father, or mother, or anyone) to marry one? In the end, the movie's a tasteless disgrace; in the battle between sweetness and nausea, nausea wins. Come back "Little House on the Prairie," all is forgiven!
The funniest joke is when the hamster dumps on everyone!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

reviews.review_title: The Nutty Professor is back (and not too badly I might add)
reviews.content:
Well, despite all the criticism (by others and me) this film can be enjoyed. Just turn your brains off, think it will be really crappy and stupid like Hot Shots 2 or Spy Hard. That's what I did and I enjoyed it (to a certain level). OK there are very stupid scenes in this one, but some really good ones too (the Armageddon dream sequence is hilarious). Plus the ending with the marriage and all is kind of sweet so my verdict is:
7 out of 10

This is one of the rare sequels that is better than the original. Eddie goes all out playing most of the major cast members. I suppose some critics and viewers will get hung up on the "poddy" humor, but it is done so quickly that it doesn't really have time to be offensive.Underneath there is a nice story about what is really important in life. If the energy of this film can be maintain in a third film, I will be glad to attend. THE KLUMPS is good fast-paced, earthy fun.

What an awful excuse for a movie. Has Eddie Murphy gotten so cheap that he won't hire other actors. He has no one to blame but himself for this travesty. No plot, no redeeming value, and very little fun. If he had hired a cast instead of doing it all himself this film MIGHT have been saved.

reviews.review_title: Nutty Professor II: The Original was Better(2000)
reviews.content: Like most Eddie Murphy sequels this one doesn't recapture the magic of the original movie. Which while was vulgar still had a heart but while this one has it's moments. One with with a hamster! The film itself is stupid! The performances are fantastic but the movie is stupid!2(**)out of 4(****)stars

reviews.review_title: A laugh riot of epic proportions
reviews.content: Being big and fat wasn't this much hilarious since Roseanne's loud, obnoxious take on "The Star-spangled Banner!" Eddie Murphy is back as Sherman Klump, Buddy Love, and the whole Klump clan in "Nutty Professor II: The Klumps," the sequel to the monster 1996 hit. This time around, it's amore extreme for Sherman, who has the hots for a new college instructor named Denise (Janet Jackson, in her first role since 1993's "Poetic Justice"), but something's not right with Sherman, because his sleazy alter ego Buddy Love is still alive and kicking! Both men are trying toget a new serum that will bring anyone's youth back, to themarket, but strange things keep happening, by the truckload!Unlike the first movie, "NPII" gives the rest of the Klumpfamily more screen presence. We get more upclose hysterics withthe whole gang more than ever, and some of the antics are down- right wild! (Check out Grandma Klump's erotic fanatasies!Yechh!!) The problems with the movie is that the flick runs over 2 hours, and the overall time might cause some discriminatingviewers to get impatient. Plus, there are a few sappy, senti- mental parts that don't really fit in with the randy, sexual jokes that run amok in this flick. But other than that, thefilm is great, and it's guaranteed to make anyone burst out laughing.

***Starring: Eddie Murphy (x 7), Janet Jackson, and Larry Miller.Everyone's favorite obese professor is back, this time creating a youth formula.  When Buddy Love becomes a terrible alter-ego, he decides to get rid of him forever by ridding of the genes.  But Buddy gets resurrected into a whole person when a strand of a dog's hair gets in his genes; thus, creating him.  Professor Klump also notices that taking Buddy out starts to make him lose intelligence, and it comes at the wrong time when he has to make a presentation for his new formula.The absence of Jada Pinkett Smith confused me, but I let that go.  the movie is hilarious, and it shows more of Murphy's other characters which make this funny.

This movie was the pits. Eddie Murphy thinks that he can be funny by talking loudly and using heavy accents. If an actor uses an accent, he could at least make sure his diction and pronunciation are intelligible to the audience. Half the message was lost on me. I couldn't understand hardly any of it. It was also crude, purile and humourless. Shame because Eddie's previous work wasn't bad at all. Lately, it's garbage.

Professor Sherman Klump (Eddie Murphy) discovers a sort of fountain of youth potion, but discovers in the process that Buddy Love (also Murphy) is back and trying to steal the potion and ruin his engagement to beautiful Janet Jackson.Sequel manges to outdo the original with twice the special effects, twice the humor, and twice the heart. Eddie Murphy is absolutely brilliant playing as many as eight roles!! ( At least that is what I counted) and Janet Jackson  is fun and appealing. The Klumps ( all of them are almost played byMurphy) make a bigger appearence ( no pun intended ) in this sequel and are a welcome addition too. Also watch the end credits, quite funny. My rating: 8 out of 10. Also features a funny Star Wars and giant monster movie spoof. GREAT FUN!!!

Is interesting i thought this sequel can be better than the first one. I have watched the first part which i can see is much more better. Although the second serial is quite emotional at the end but there are still lacks of something inside.The camera simply move too fast from one person to the other and the language is too fast to be understand. Viewer probably find it a bit sick if they have motion sickness.Overall, can be better.

reviews.review_title: Klumps suffers a mild case of sequelitis.
reviews.content: When seeing the trailers for NUTTY PROFESSOR II: THE KLUMPS, I was rolling my eyes saying, "why make a sequel to a good comedy?" I'm pleased to say that KLUMPS is entertaining, but not as good as the original (sequelitis).  No, the last movie that over came sequelitis is TOY STORY 2, so it will be about another few more years until we see a sequel better than it's predecessor.      KLUMPS has Eddie Murphy returning as Professor Sherman Klump, a man who's waist is awfully big, but so is his heart. Also returning is Mama, Papa, Ernie, and Grandma Klump, all played by Murphy.  And making a unwelcome return is the vicious and cruel alter-ego of Sherman, Buddy Love.  Sherman is suffering from saying or doing cruel and rude remarks from the Buddy Love gene inside his body.  Sherman is very worried, because he wants to start a serious relationship with his colleague, Denice Gains (Janet Jackson).  But it's the Buddy in him that holding Sherman up.  So Sherman decides to take that gene out of him, causing Sherman to lose his intelligence more and more every second.  And even worse, Buddy manage to come into form from a piece of dog DNA, causing Buddy to actually act like a dog! Buddy first appears in a nice homage to the classic film noir film CAPE FEAR. And poor Papa Klump, he's suffering from a "limp noodle" it seems that he can't get it up anymore.  Mama Klump suggests viagria, but Papa replies that he's been taking them like, "M & M's."  And Sherman also invented a youth formula, that is worth millions, and Dean Richmond (Larry Miller) only cares about getting that check in his hand, and could care less about Sherman's diminishing intelligence. There are some parts in KLUMPS that are just downright funny.  I was laughing my head off at some of the scenes.  Then I was rather shocked to see some of the other scenes.  I was shocked because it was rather obscene, and it's in a PG-13 movie, when it's along the same lines as ME, MYSELF, & IRENE. But KLUMPS does manage to have plenty of funny scenes to make it worthwhile. I figured out that any recent funny Eddie Murphy movie is funny is when Murphy isn't playing himself. BOWFINGER, the original NUTTY PROFESSOR, and this film are all funny since Murphy plays a variety of characters that shows the great talent that Murphy has.  Where in films like DOCTOR DOLITTLE and LIFE, Murphy is playing his usual role, and makes it very dull.  It was funny back in the '80's, but it's rather old now.  And I don't know why Janet Jackson replaced Jada Pinkett?  I mean, Jackson isn't horrible playing Sherman's love interest, but she really doesn't stand out.  And Larry Miller is a little less colder than he was in the original NUTTY, but he does manage to shoot some some cruel remarks to Sherman. I was rather pleased to see that the sequel was filmed on the campus of University of Southern California.  I was attending USC for summer school when I first saw the original NUTTY PROFESSOR.  I brought back good memories seeing the campus, and seeing the familiar faces of the Klump family also brought back good memories. KLUMPS is a comedy that ranks in the middle of funny films for the year.  It's not as funny as CHICKEN RUN or ROAD TRIP. But it's way more funnier than BIG MOMMA'S HOUSE and READY TO RUMBLE. However, I think that Eddie Murphy should put the Klump routine to rest, and think of a clever character that's far from his normal personality, like his Jiff character from BOWFINGER.  KLUMPS is o.k., but see it after you've see everything else this summer.  ***1/3 (out of five)

Short, sweet, brilliant touches of sentiment and occasional flashes of brilliance do not make up for some jokes that are so poorly conceived that they are embarrassing to watch.The true genius in this new Eddie Murphy vehicle is in the editing and multiple characterizations that Mr. Murphy accomplishes so successfully.His characters, while all belonging to the same family, are diverse enough and he performs them consistently enough that they become believable as individuals. The seamless editing certainly enhances the performance(s) by Mr. Murphy.There is quite a bit of juvenile, bathroom humour  which doesn't particularly appeal to me  but most of the rest of the audience seemed to enjoy it.Casting Janet Jackson was genius; she is very good as the sweet and supportive Denise Gains.  But I did wonder why she was cast when there are so many other underutilized African American actresses that could have been showcased.  Was it for her box office drawing power?  Or did she just need the money?The make up department will probably be nominated for all the major awards (Golden Globe, Oscar, etc.) and will probably walk away with at least one of them.However, one of the most appealing aspects of this movie was the superb soundtrack  it was magnificently composed, wonderfully orchestrated and perfectly performed.

I gave the original an 8. This one was about a 6.6, but rounded to a 7.I was again very impressed with the job Murphy did. He is a genius to be sure. And, the make-up was sensational. Having said that, it doesn't make a movie.There was a little comedy and it had a sweet feel to it. But, the crude behavior was the only thing that allowed me to err on the side of a 7 versus lower. I like crude.Unfortunately, since that is what the movie was about, it didn't have enough and what it had wasn't funny most of the time.I would NOT go see a third version of this movie. There is simply no way it could offer anything beyond what the first to offered. The "joke" really started to get old by the end of the movie and I can only imagine that a third version would be a disaster.

reviews.review_title: Don't let the ads klump your mind
reviews.content: Hollywood is making us believe that this is the best comedy around ever. I think they are trying to klump our brains with vulgar jokes which are pretty stupid to say the least.I can't believe this movie is number one.I did not laugh once and preferred The Nutty Professor 1 over this movie. Again, this is an affirmation of the rule: THE SEQUEL IS NEVER AS GOOD AS THE ORIGINAL.Save your money, go watch the movie "The Kid" instead with Bruce Willis. Raphael Abbate

This film confirms Eddie Murphy's slide into movie mediocrity. This is almost 100% toilet humour. Virtually none of the jokes raise even a fraction of a ripple of a smile. Its awful in every way, nothing endears it to viewers. Anybody who buys this film needs instant surgery to correct their mind. Its a terrible offering. That money has been paid for the Klumps is a disgrace. All profits should be confiscated and given to charity or something. It horrifies me that people have earned money from a film so amazingly bad. Murphy seems to play every character, but in any role he fails to entertain. The Klumps is another of those sorry cash-ins that try and relive the glory of the first movie, which in this case was adequate at best.

This movie was a tedious 1.45 hours.  I sat there in awe of how unbelievably awful it truly was.  There was so much of the dialogue I couldn't understand (when the Klumps would converse) and the storyline and plot just was awful. Do yourselves a favor and don't see it.  You'll be checking your watch every 5 minutes and wishing you were 8 dollars richer.

Another comedy bites the dust. I didn't laugh once during themovie. The whole thing was stupid. The only thing that amusedme was watching Eddie Murphy play almost the entire Klumpfamily.NOT RECOMMENDED.3.5 out of 10

reviews.review_title: Uncreative and raunchy... I wouldn't advise watching this while eating
reviews.content: This was on the living room TV one Saturday evening, and I was trying to enjoy a slice of pizza to no avail. Nutty Professor II: The Klumps was a waste of money to make. It was stupid and gross. Absolute cringe from start to finish. The characters don't do anything but talk about sex and pass gas. To be honest I didn't think the first movie was all that great either, when Professor Klump's family was passing gas at the dinner table. How is that funny? It's ignorant and vulgar. Only kids laugh at that nonsense. Adults who think that's funny make me lose faith in humanity. The humor is just too off the wall for my taste. The grandmother stripping down to her birthday suit, and then forcing Professor Klump's alter ego to kiss her, was awful. The scene with the giant hamster wasn't any better. That was highly disturbing. No way is this on my list of favorite movies. I will give Eddie Murphy props - it takes a lot of talent to play more than one character. But the flatulence and sex jokes were overdone. I'm skinny and I even found it offensive how overweight people were portrayed as disgusting. I know my review is 22 years late, but nonetheless, please do better, Hollywood! Movies influence how people see each other. They're a contributing factor to racial and gender stereotypes. Maybe it's because I studied the behavioral and social sciences in college, but I honestly do believe how people treat one another in society will not improve until films start improving, and that includes comedies. If you think toilet humor and sexual dialogue are hilarious, then you will enjoy yourself. This film wasn't my cup of tea, and neither was the original for that matter.

beautiful film. As to the usual one, the usual negative comments which talk about a classical film some years 80 which everyone does not like it to the nostalgic ones are met.Sure Heros that this film had to have a judgment in this site. In fact reviewers' good part has put a high vote to the previous episodes. Because this contrast? I know the reason. Since assumptive reviewers' good part favorably sees the past and as the past is "better" than the present they have given several credit to the preceding episodes being still the last episode more explosive and spectacular. At this point should reject also the old episodes but there are here two weights and two measure.In fact also cinema masterpieces have been criticized and denigrated. Good part some reviewers of this site belong to the very bad reviewers. Better think separately with its head. I was sure that the god fun old episode did not like it. Who has to be withdrawn is not george lucas but the last reviewer SAMPAT

This is the worst movie ever made. Throughout the movie I found myself trying to leave, even though it was my own house. The jokes were not funny in the least, and all the punchlines could be seen from a mile away or were overly built up. I love Eddie Murphy, but I don't know what he was thinking during the making of this pile of worthless film.

"Nutty Professor 2" is a very, very funny movie, it is Eddie Murphy's best and funniest film since "Dr. Dolittle" from 1998.  Eddie Murphy plays six roles in this film, it is a real treat to watch him do his thing. Though the film goes the toilet humor route in parts it is still very funny and I recommend it .

reviews.review_title: to sick for it's own good
reviews.content:
I'm a pretty casual Eddie Murphy fan.  I love the Beverly Hills Cop movies. I loved Coming to America more than any other Eddie Murphy movie.  I also loved the first Murphy Nutty Professor.  It had the right combination between tasteless toilet humor and tasteful humor.  Well, the sequel isn't like the original.I will admit, most of the movie is funny.  The whole bit about Buddy Love being part dog is hilarious.  There is some classic Murphy humor here. However, most of the movie is filled with fart jokes, `poop' gags, and sex humor.  When I say sex humor, I don't mean humor like Austin Powers One.  I mean old people shagging.  Who wants to watch old people talk about acts that would make a 13-year-old blush?Now, I can take toilet humor.  It ain't my favorite brand of humor. Honestly I prefer intelligent, yet silly movies like This is Spinal Tap, Clerks, Caddyshack, Monty Python, and, hell, even Adam Sandler.  Let's not forget the Simpsons!  Well, The Nutty Professor II is just fart jokes, and I found the movie to be completely tasteless and disgusting.  Like I said, I thought the first Eddie Murphy: Nutty Professor was a classic.  But this new one is just too much.Immature teenagers will love this movie.  Anyone who has any maturity will not.  I saw this with my dad, and almost convinced me to leave the theater. I would have done that, but I have a philosophy of "If I paid for it, I'm going try and get my money's worth".So, basically, if you like Eddie Murphy, do see this movie.  Some jokes are funny. (some spoiling) The end of the movie is terribly sappy, especially how Sherman Klump and Dean Richmond just become friends for no reason. They're supposed to hate each other, and they quickly become friends really quickly.  I wish Murphy had done more with this movie than fart jokes.  I really do. 
I will say that the visual effects are pretty amazing.  Seeing how every character is Eddie Murphy in makeup is just astounding!  They pass food around the table in an un-cut, 360 degree swoop, they sit watching television while slapping each other on the back, and they even attend a party where they crisscross through the crowd all in the same shot.  Truly amazing.Eddie Murphy is a genius, but he doesn't show it here.
4/10

The first Nutty Professor was actually a funny remake of the now legendary Jerry Lewis movie. In some ways actually funnier than its original. This sequel is almost not at all funny. As much farting as there is a lack of story which is quite a lot. There are a few witty moments but most of the time Eddie Murphy dirt talks his way through his many roles. How incredibly he may mask himself he fails to make actual dialog between the characters and the talking quickly becomes a tiring cacophony of words.Thomas Nielsen

Even though the title is annoying, I thought "The Klumps" was better than the first. Sure, its jokes are somewhat disgusting, but it's still surprisingly touching. The plot is interesting and you can't help but fall for the Klump family.
Eddie Murphy runs wild through this comedy. I enjoyed getting to know the Klumps family. A laugh riot!!

reviews.review_title: I liked the first one a lot more
reviews.content: A sequel is never great but I gave this movie a 4 because it wasn't very funny and it was way too long for a movie like this
I didn't like it. Nope. Not very much at all. That's why I gave it only three stars.

I think we all have relatives, in-laws and family members that we could identify with in `The Nutty Professor 2'although they may not be as extreme as some of these characters.This movie is basically the `Eddie Murphy Show' as he plays the entire Klump family. The basic story line revolves around Sherman Klump developing the formula for age reversal. Somewhere along the way, Buddy Love (Sherman's alter self) gets his hands on it and decides that he's going to be the one to reap the benefits of this youth formula.   I don't want to give away too much of the plot and ruin it for you.The makeup in this movie was fantastic. The fat suits that Murphy wears are so realistic and follow his movements so well that you think these characters were real. He plays all the characters so differently but at the same time with a hint of similarity that it's not hard to believe that they're all related to each other. He particularly plays Grandma Klump well. She is such a riot and so is Mother Klump. It seems that Eddie Murphy's career is starting to turn the corner.Janet Jackson plays Sherman's girlfriend moderately well. It wasn't great but it wasn't badjust ok. At times she seemed to look like she was struggling to find the right way to display the emotion the particular scene called for but otherwise she was fine. She will get better as she gains more experience.The one thing that may have taken away from this movie was that it may have had one too many crude toilet jokes. Most of them were inserted at the right moment but there was the odd one that wasn't really necessary and could potentially have been annoying.Overall, this was an entertaining movie. If nothing else, see this movie just to see Eddie's different characters.

reviews.review_title: Lots of laughs, but without much plot and the heart of the original movie
reviews.content: "The Klumps" was mediocre and least a bit better than I'd expected form the trailers.  The original movie had a little more heart to it and Murphy was more original.  In "The Klumps", the emphasis was much more on the family, and you knew all of the jokes either from the trailers, the previous movie, or your own sense of prediction.  Sure, there were some laughs, but they were immature (as expected) and a lot less original.  Eddie Murphy, however is a funny man, and his spontaneity puts some life into the roles of the Klumps (five of them!).  The movie was good for a light-hearted night, or maybe a kid's slumber party.

reviews.review_title: The Nutty Professor was Brilliant! The Nutty Professor 2 is awful!
reviews.content: THE NUTTY PROFESSOR (1996) starring Eddie Murphy and Jada Pinkett was, and still is, one of my all-time favourite movies. But this is a huge dissapointment.The movie ut toilet gags and rambling. Yes OK  the SFX are still there but the director just exploits the SFX in this movie and the whole thing is completely overglossed and overdone! The scenes at the dinner table in the first movie (where Eddie plays the 5 characters) was hilirious and worked very well...in this movie it doesn't! The scenes in this movie are just so repetetive and un-inventive. The toilet humour is just pathetic. The writers must have been so low on ideas when they wrote this trash! WHAT A HUGE FAILURE COMPARED TO THE FIRST MOVIE! 2/10

reviews.review_title: Superior sequel - but NOT for the kiddies!
reviews.content: My hubby wanted to see this so I tagged along, not exactly looking forward to the experience since I was NOT a fan of the Murphy version of "The Nutty Professor", a lousy remake/update if ever there was one (ditto for "Doctor Doolittle"): Murphy, a man I have never been particularly fond of, just tried WAY too hard and wasn't that funny, to be honest. Now, however, while at times he STILL has a tendency to overplay (a problem he shares with Robin Williams; both require a strong-handed director to guide them toward FULL AND SATISFYING performances), he is much more successful and so is the film, a fact also due to what can only be called an often hilarious, occasionally draggy, sometimes sentimental, usually raunchy - and I mean RAUNCHY! - screenplay. As another review here as said, in this film Sherman finds a way to 'remove' the lingering Buddy Love from his system, only to find out that Buddy just won't stay put; in fact, Buddy has designs on a fountain-of-youth formula that Sherman has developed and schemes to steal not only the formula but the glory - and triple-digit millions - too. That's the basic outline. Interspersed is more of the Klump family than previously seen (in more ways than one), and it is here that perhaps the movie is most rewarding: while Sherman is the gently-lovable center of the film, the bulk (for lack of a better term) of their scenes, deftly played for maximum laughs by Murphy and brilliantly edited for boffo impact, is provided by Mama & Papa Klump (touching and hysterical) and Granny, whose character neatly and efficiently steals every scene (particularly memorable is the portion of her Buddy Love dream sequence where she joyously frolics in a sea of wildflowers). Though given a few choice lines, the brother Klump character is pretty much relegated to the sidelines, while the grandson is silent and wasted (if you've seen the portion of the preview where he guzzles soft-serve ice cream straight from the spout, you've just seen the only substantial moment he has); as for the character of Buddy Love, it seems, wisely, that there have been considerable pains to make him a little toned-down and a bit more cartoonish; previously, he was simply too mean and it dragged down the movie, giving it a harsh edge it didn't need. That's changed, somewhat, though his - and, to a lesser degree, Larry Miller's - fat jokes and putdowns get rather tiresome. As a whole, the film succeeds, though, like "Big Momma's House" (a film it often resembles) it gets quite a bit funnier as it goes along (the beginning tends to drag here and there); unlike "Big Momma's House", however, this film is downright BAWDY and remarkably vulgar!!! (The transformation is similar to that of "Austin Powers" - cult-like original, down-and-dirty gross-out-giggly sequel.) I could see a mother in the audience visibly squirming every time one of the myriad references to sex acts was uttered and while they were indeed absolutely funny-as-hell, it must be said this ain't for kids. Be assured: THIS IS REALLY AN ADULT'S FILM IN DISGUISE! As for the performances, this is, naturally, Eddie Murphy's film and he is obviously having a ball; at slower points in the movie, one is able to take a breath and admire the man for what seems like boundless energy. His performances - eight, in all - are noteworthy, to say the very least, and he manages to even invest these characters with a most important trait: humanity. You really do believe these are people with honest-to-goodness feelings. As Sherman's love interest, Janet Jackson, looking stunning and photographed beautifully, gives a fine performance, and makes a warm presence, a total turnaround from her previous big-screen appearance in "Poetic Justice". Perhaps wisely, she is given NO comedic readings. (For proof that comedy should be left to comedians, just tune in to ANY episode of  "Hollywood Squares.) In a repeat supporting performance, Larry Miller offers nothing new to his repertoire but is still a hoot (particularly following an incident involving a hamster). Other performances are OK with no standouts, though occasionally extras are woefully wooden. The look of the film is bright and cheery, like the original. Apparently, the director decided to give the reigns to Murphy, but still the movie moves along pretty briskly, for the most part. Overall, a darn funny film...just not for the kiddies.

reviews.review_title: This is the worst movie I've ever seen.
reviews.content: This is the worst movie I've ever seen. There was nothing good about it at all. It was entirely bad. I normally like Eddie Murphy in his other movies (Dr. Doolittle was cute, Trading Places was hilarious). This was just flat out awful, no way around it. The plot stunk. Eddie Murphy was too busy playing all the characters to make any of them good. Everything stunk. I'm done.

Nutty Professor II is a very funny sequel. Close to being as good as the original, but the original is a tad better. Some of the jokes in this movie are outrageous. Like the scene with the giant hamster. Eddie Murphy is as funny and likeable as ever as Sherman Klump. The Klumps are hilarious too. Overall not quite as good as the original, but close. *** (out of four)

This movie is great! The movie pushes the limits of a PG-13 rating TOO FAR, but who cares. Here's a warning to parents, this is NOT a movie for small kids. They'll say, "Mommy, what are they doing in the bed?". I was shocked in my theater to see kids about 3 SEEING THE MOVIE! Anyway, good movie.**** out of ****

Nutty Professor 2: The Klumps is sequel to the remade version of The Nutty Professor. The movie is about nice Sherman Klump who is about to be married to an entirely person from the first movie and tries to make his sleek and evil alter ego a separate person. He succeeds, but finds himself getting dumber and dumber just as he's about to make a presentation about a new thing he created, which ends up horribly inappropriate. The plot is remotely interesting, but ridiculous and meaningless. It's fine that if a sequel isn't as funny as its predecessor, but filling every scene with a forced sexual innuendo or a bathroom joke is not good, it's just wrong.The first movie had the same kind of material, but there were other jokes that were used. Just watch the first movie, the original Disney version, or even the classic Robert Louis Stevenson book "Dr. Jeykll and Mr. Hyde." My Rating: */*****

Grossed-out comedy with an interesting plot that could have saved it. I suspect the movie would have been a lot better if it were made as a Sci-Fi or drama. The jokes were simply lame and over-cliched already. It's got some original ideas. Let's hope some other director/writer can come up with a better movie.

Picking up where he left off in the original, Eddie Murphy is superb playing 8 different roles as Professor Sherman Klump and his hilariously raucous family, the Klumps.  But this one falls well short of the original because when the Klumps aren't on the screen there is little reason to watch. Director Segal forms a barebones script around Murphy's performances, and then decides to not give us as much of the Klumps as we desire (and deserve).  Two definite low points: Janet Jackson as a molecular scientist (yeah, right) and a brand of disgusting, lowest denominator humor more familiar coming the Farrely brothers.  After seeing a giant hamster shoot terds out of its rear-end and sexually assault Sherman's boss, I began to wonder about the PG-13 rating.  The makeup is incredible, once again, but Murphy deserves a better supporting case and script next time around (which will surely come soon).  Preceded by `The Nutty Professor.'

reviews.review_title: How many fart jokes can one movie have?
reviews.content: If you like bathroom humor, you'll love this movie.  Murphy is a very talented man, as his multiple character portrayals reveals, all of which are very funny.  The addition of Grandma's lover is hilarious, and little brother, Hercules, is even fatter than in the first movie!  All in all, you should have quite a few laughs at this flick, even though you may be a little embarrassed that you're laughing.

reviews.review_title: Too much of a good thing..
reviews.content: How much can you really expect of a film containing giant hampsters, naked grannies and Eddie Murphy behaving like a dog (literally)? Unfortunately, most attempts at humour were crude to the point of evoking disgust, offence or substandard raunchiness, the combination of which isn't all that funny. The repeated heavy focus on Eddie Murphy meant it needed a remarkable solo effort to steal the show but 'The Klumps' was devoid of the charm and Murphy dazzle of its predecessor. The makeup remained the one admirable point. The more time the camera revolves around the rest of the Klumps has you appreciating the brilliance of the makeup, which adds to each character in its own individual way. The bantering and squabbling between the mother and father and even the grandma at times, overshadows the main relationship between Murphy and Janet Jackson's characters which is fraught with standardism and monotony. Though, on this occasion, grandma's mutterings don't hold as much value as they did in the first film and become hit and miss in the humour stakes at best. Apart from the odd brief section here and there, it was an asinine attempt at humour which bordered upon facetious at times.

Congratulations: this is one of the three (3) movies in my life i went out from. And it was when the top of fun was a space movement based on farts (or so i believe, i was dozing anyways). Dull, obvious, un-funny, recycled, stale jokes. I am not against cheap, bodily humor - but even fart jokes can be funny or not. Those are not. A new standard in bad comedies.

What they should have called this movie was "Let's take the funniest parts of the first Nutty Professor, do them to death, and fill in the rest of the movie with...," I think you get the idea.  Unlike the 1996 edition of The Nutty Professor, I did not find the Klumps funny in the sequel.  Rather, they were crude and silly.  The plot was very unoriginal - except for the fact that Janet Jackson played the leading lady in this one rather than Jada Pinkett, it almost mirrored the first one.  And the jokes?  Also rude, crude, and disgusting.  Now let me get this perfectly clear.  I am not a prude.  I like dirty jokes, but they have to be good jokes, which these ones were not.  Perhaps the funniest line, I thought, was the one which Buddy Love compares the taste of some red punch to Mogen David wine.  Do I have anything good to say about the movie?  Yes.  Freda Payne played a great cameo, and I also enjoyed the excerpt of "Cape Fear" with Gregory Peck.  I think I'll pass on the next Nutty Professor sequel should they write another one.

reviews.review_title: Fat Jokes Starting To Wear Thin
reviews.content: Starts out hilarious at first with the wedding sequence at the beginning which turns out to be a dream sequence in Sherman's mind, but one can only take so much of the toilet humor and ribbing about fatness and obesity after a while. Apart from the main characters Sherman and Buddy, Eddie Murphy reprises his multiple roles as each of the family members of the Klump family with the exception of the youngest son, and proves his versatility in playing different characters. A pity that there's more emphasis on the fart gags and sexual innuendo than in the actual plot of retrieving the scientific formula and banishing the obnoxious Buddy Love from Sherman's genetic existence. Eddie Murphy is a talented comedic actor, but I hope there is not going to be another sequel to this movie. Time to move on, Eddie.

reviews.review_title: You sure Eddie wasn't trying to make a Horror Movie?
reviews.content: Unlike most people who use different genres as a means of negatively bashing the movie. I mean this in the utmost respect. When you ignore the vulgarity and the other things, both Klumps and the first movie are famous for, you get a movie about two sides of one persona at war with each other and the other side pulling no stops to destroy each other. In the first movie, Buddy was just another part of Sherman's persona, but now that he's been unleashed into the world with none of Sherman's love and common sense to restrain him he becomes a deranged lunatic. He even gives De Niro a run for his money when parodying the Cape Fear Theater scene.

reviews.review_title: After this, I never want to see Eddie Murphy again
reviews.content: Crude,tired humor; muddled plot; way--WAY--too long.  This movie is not worth the time spent seeing it.  Everything that was good and funny about the original has been wrung out in the sequel, and what we get instead is a series of disgusting, puerile attempts at slapstick, which come off as crude rather than funny.  You just want the whole thing to stop, but it goes on, and on, and on, and on . . . .
The acting is bad, the humour is tasteless and unfunny.

A hopeless sequel that resorts to using fart gags and movie send-ups to pad out the story. The worst part was that given its PG rating here in Australia, I made the mistake of taking some young children with me. Because of some crude scenes, the film is not really suitable for kids.

reviews.review_title: Murphy gives 2000's best performance by a male actor so far
reviews.content: I've always liked Eddie Murphy, but I did expect more from the first Nutty Professor movie. Freed from the burden of living up to the 1963 film, Murphy built on the strengths of his original Nutty Professor movie. He gave another sensitive portrayal of Sherman Klump. We got to spend way more time with the family and he toned down Buddy Love's presence in this sequel, giving us no more Buddy than we needed. His acting ability has grown in leaps and bounds in recent years, to the point where his performances are superior to the movies they're in. That was the case with the first Nutty Professor and Metro. I thought his best work was in Bowfinger, but now I'm routing for him to get an Oscar nomination. I was stunned by his sensitive portrayal of Mama and Papa Klump and his handling of their marital problems. His performance likely won't be given the respect it deserves because of the crude humour involving hamster droppings and bodily functions, but I would like to see Eddie Murphy's achievement in this film properly acknowledged.

reviews.review_title: Good sequel, but could've been better!
reviews.content: After having just sat through a rather interesting sequel, I thought I should give my two cents on it.  If you look at my voting on this, I gave it a 7 mainly due to special effects, along with strong performances from Janet Jackson, nice to see her on screen, as well as Eddie Murphy who played just about everyone.   However, it most certainly could've done better (overall I think it did a good job), but in all fairness, it had a lot of shoes to fill sort of speak because of the first Nutty Professor Movie, which I thought was just outright funny and gave a good spin on the Jerry Lewis classic.  This second run of the mill for Professor lacked the spontaneity and zest of the first film, where the feeling of "been there done that" more of less plagued me throughout the film.  Don't get me wrong though, it did have it moments to try and stay interesting and make up for the lags, not only from what I mentioned above, but three classic scenes in particular were: the opening dream sequence, the gerbil mishap at the presentation, and the final sequence with the Professor getting his revenge on Buddy.Overall if you're a fan of this Saturday Night veteran or a nutty professor fan, you're sure to like this movie.  I would most certainly look forward to a third Nutty Professor Film.Overall rating: 3.5 out of 5

ALL MY REVIEWS CONTAIN SPOILERS.  EVERY ONE OF THEM.
Eddie Murphy is a genius.  His rhythm, his timing and his performances in "Nutty Professor 2: The Klumps" are flawless.  Scenes involving him to play every single character at any given time are acts of brilliance.  One problem.  The movie sucks.I enjoyed the first Nutty, and up to about 30 minutes into the sequel, I was having a ball.  Eddie broke new grounds in the first, and he was taking it to an even further level in part 2.  While watching, I said to myself, "Eddie, the master of disguise, has done it again."  Then, the actual movie kicked in.Unfortunately, Janet Jackson will probably always be a bad casting choice in any role, simply because she is Janet Jackson.  Her stardom is so huge, that whenever I see her on screen, all I can see is her, not her character.  I had the same problem with 1993's "Poetic Justice."  That and the fact that that movie sucked, too.  And yeah, I know-- famous recording artists have made names for themselves in Hollywood (Madonna, Will Smith.)  But Janet seems so..."Janet" to me.  I dunno, maybe it's because she can't act.  At least, she can't act ANYMORE; we all felt for her as poor Penny, the burn victim from "Good Times."  God, I wanted to beat her mamma's a**.Here, she plays Denise Gaines, Sherman Klump's fiance and fellow scientist. She is complete and utter eye candy, which I have no problem with.  As fine as she is, while watching the film, I was sooo full.  In the film, Sherman fights split personality Buddy Love, who is still trapped inside his DNA. Buddy lives within Sherman, and occasionally pops out of Sherman's personality without warning, making life for the fat man miserable. Sherman is forced to eventually make a genetic split, externalizing Buddy Love.
This is where the film sloooowws down, almost to a halt.  Things got so dull at one point, I began to daydream, looking around the theater for single women who may need some Rocky the Bear in their lives.  When the action finally picked back up in the end, things got so crazy, zany, and yes, I'm going to say it...NUTTY, that the film becomes everything but animated. At some points I felt the movie was targeted for kids, but then a d*ck joke, or a fart joke, or say, a SODOMIZING joke would change my mind, so I don't know WHO this film is aimed at.  2 stars, simply off of Eddie's brilliant performances as the Klump family alone.  * * out of 5.
What the $%&#.....OK......Hmmmm..... Not funny, Not entertaining, Not worth the plastic it was encoded onto. GOD AWFUL!!!

I understand that the AFI will not be putting this movie into the top 100 comedies of the 21st century, but the bottom line is that its funny and has many laugh out loud scenes in it. It is by far the funniest movie to come out this year. And why are people claiming there is no story line? The story line is that the Professor Klump has invented a youth serum and Buddy Love, the evil alter ego, is trying to steal it for his own. What more storyline does a comedy need? In addition there are many sub-plots: 1.The love story between Professor Klump and  Denise Gaines (Janet Jackson), 2.The impotency problem of Old Man Klump, 3.Professor Klump losing his intelligence, 4.The impending marriage between the Professor and Denise. This movie has a much better plot than either Me, Myself, and Irene and Scary Movie.Also, I think Eddie Murphy deserves a lot of credit for creating these multiple characters and giving each one of them a life of their own. Technologically, nothing like this has ever been done as well as it has here. (Multiplicity tried, but failed miserably). Sure this isn't Dr. Strangelove, but so what, it's funny.

This movie is better than the original Nutty Professor with Eddie Murphy, but it is much nastier. This should've been given an R rating, but then again, R movies are getting a lot nastier every year it seems. Most of the funny parts come from the nastiness, but sometimes this movie can be quite charming. If you liked the original, then I reccomend going to see this movie. It's funny, but is directly aimed for adults, which is most obvious.

Reading all the negative reviews about this film I figured a nice positive one would help. I thought "Nutty Professor II: The Klumps" was hysterical. The first one was terrific, but I think this blows it away. Eddie Murphy really plays the whole Klump family, as Sherman develops a youth serum and asks his girlfriend Denise Gains (Janet Jackson) to marry him. Papa and Mama are having problems with their sex life, Ernie is just annoying and Grandma (who is the best character in this movie) is totally over-sexed. Buddy Love also emerges from Sherman's body and is now a separate person, wanting to get his hands on the youth serum to earn lots of money. I guess I'm a sucker for toilet humor and sex jokes! I thought Grandma was a riot, especially in the fantasy sequence with Buddy and the dinner scene in the restaurant was hysterical. I was almost on the floor rolling with laughter. I thought Sherman's dream sequence was dumb and they could have explained a little bit of what happened to Carla Purty (played by Jada Pinkett in the original). She's nowhere to be found here, except for a very brief mention of her. The film is definitely more raunchier than the original, but for some reason, I thought the jokes worked well. This is NOT a movie for young kids. Good sequel. Hope for "Nutty Professor III" in the future! Nice job Eddie!

Since the plot of this movie is not the reason to go see it, I won't even try to explain what the movie is about.  I'll just give the positive and negatives and let you decide for yourself.<u>Positives</u>1. The Granny character is hilarious.  The dream sequence of she and Buddy Love running in a field of flowers had me rolling.2. The dumb Uncle was an okay character but not really necessary.3. The clapping momma character was funny.4. The fat nephew wasn't necessary.  He didn't say one word throughout the movie; he did burp.5. Janet Jackson was good as Buddy's love interest but I thought her voice seemed a little too young for the character she was supposedly playing.6. The father character was funny.7. The nutty professor character and his assistant were necessary for the film.<u>Negatives</u>1. I don't like fart jokes and this movie had a lot of them.2. Sometimes nothing at all happened during the movie.3. Granny's boyfriend ate a choked up piece of meat and that was just GROSS
Overall, the movie was very entertaining.

reviews.review_title: It Breaks My Heart To Rate This 2
reviews.content: I love almost all Eddie Murphy movies. I even enjoyed him in I Spy. I rented Pluto Nash on pay per view (watched it on my descrambler.) But this.... I saw this in the theater, and when I woke up and he was farting in space, I left the theater. That's all I have to say about that.

The Nutty Professor was, in my opinion, the return of Eddie Murphy's greatness.  The best parts of that film were the dinner scenes with the Klumps.  So, naturally a sequel would be made that featured the family for the entire movie.  My first reaction to such a sequel was bad.  I thought that The Klumps would be a typical sequel in which the characters were milked for only their funny one-liners.  If you want to know what I'm talking about, watch Austin Powers 2 compared to the first.  I thought that The Klumps would be a detestable movie with no heart.  I thought wrong.It is true that since There's Something About Mary movies have gone that extra mile to make themselves grosser.  However, the one thing that movie had above those since, was a heart.  That heart was what made you endure the sickness that ensued.  The Klumps has a lot of crude jokes, including a rather unsavory segment with a giant hamster.  But the film's large (pun intended), heart was what made it memorable.  Janet Jackson does a very good job as Sherman Klump's fiance, giving him a much more meaningful relationship than in the first film.  Sherman is still the star, but the other characters get their valuable screen time.  In the first film, the Klumps were nothing more than a joke.  In this one, they each have meaningful characterization.  That is what makes The Klumps much better than it first appears.If The Klumps has one flaw, it is the pacing.  The movie starts out so fast that you barely have time to comprehend everything.  However, this is corrected as the film progresses.Besides being the funniest movie of the year so far, The Klumps is a story of love, marriage, and family.  It is one of those movies that makes you smile.  It leaves you with that warm, fuzzy feeling in your stomach, and unlike most comedy sequels, it isn't rising vomit.

reviews.review_title: The Most Average Movie I Have Ever Seen!
reviews.content: Some movies are good. This is good. Some movies are bad. This is bad, but can sometimes be good. And then there are movies that are okay. Nutty Professor II: The Klumps is okay. And by okay, I mean the most mundane, middle-of-the-road average movie I've seen.  It's neither bad nor good.  I watched it and was left feeling neither pleased or displeased. It is simply filler.  The occasional extremely gross gag is put in to trick you into thinking you're watching something other than a simply okay movie.  If this review seems vague, that's because that's how this movie made me feel. I don't like it or hate it, I just know that I have seen it, and it hasn't affected me in any way.  So if you just want to see something that will kill 90 minutes, you could do no better or worse than to see Nutty Professor II: The Klumps.

Nutty Professor II: The Klumps (2000)Starring: Eddie Murphy, Eddie Murphy, Eddie Murphy and Eddie MurphyPlot: The entire Klump family returns as Sherman develops another body altering potion. Quick Take: Definitely `nutty' but lacking much of a story.2 out of 5In Eddie Murphy's first Nutty Professor remake, the Klump family dinner was one of the most entertaining segments in the film. So its no surprise that he decided to create an entire film around this oddball group of characters and `technically' the film is a success.  In some scenes, you have no choice but to believe that Eddie Murphy has been cloned six times in order to create the illusion you're seeing.  In addition, the makeup guru of Hollywood, Rick Baker, has once again outdone himself with his near flawless creations.But the flaws in the story are not so easily hidden.  Sherman Klump along with the professor he has fallen in love with (Janet Jackson), have developed a new potion that will make its user young again.  But his alter ego, Buddy Love (Murphy's most annoying character), decides to steal it for himself creating problems for Sherman and the entire Klump family. Predictable and tiresome, the script ends up becoming just another vehicle for Murphy and his creative characters.Without an interesting story the characters have nowhere to go and we're left with a film full of bathroom humor and slapstick comedy which becomes old fast and too often skirts the line of its PG-13 rating.2 out of 5
A lazy sequel to the quite funny original film from 96,Feels like a bunch of sketches stitched together avoid at all costs.

**********NUTTY PROFESSOR II**********The Plot: Professor Sherman Klump (Eddie Murphy) is living unhappily as a scientist genius at a university. He is unhappy because he still has a part of the evil Buddy Love (Eddie Murphy) inside him. When Sherman proposes to scientist sweetheart Denise Gaines (Janet Jackson) he gets Buddy Love's genes out of him so he can be perfect. Yet does Klump know that he will be worse without Buddy in him 60%The Acting: Eddie Murphy is simply amazing. He plays all of the 7 Klumps plus Buddy Love and Lance Perkins, if only he had chosen to play 7 characters in better film! Anyway, Jackson is also quite impressive as Professor Denise Gaines. 75%The Screenplay/Directing: Just why did we need another Nutty Professor? The first film had an original screenplay, this screenplay is just another silly try at been a good sequel. The directing is equally terrible. Perhaps if as much effort when into the make-up as went into the script, we would have been onto a winner. 28%Other: The make-up in awesome, it is an effective turn on the film. But the jokes are largely unfunny and pointless. From the very start, you can tell there is not going to be anything special about Nutty Professor II: The Klumps. 60%Overall: This is a really poor sequel. It is not one of those movies that is so bad you have to see it, it is just a pointless waste of time. 43%**********NUTTY PROFESSOR II 43%**********

What a great disappointment! This film is much much worse than "The nutty professor I", although the trailer was very good.Unlike in the first movie, the plot here is absolutely moronic and mostly non-existent. It would be hard  to come up with a worse script! There are a few good jokes with nothing to fill the space between them. I don't mind low-brow humor, but most jokes here do not qualify as "humor", just "low-brow" and indeed degenerate.Eddie Murphy does an excellent job playing several characters at the same time, but it is not enough to salvage this pathetic excuse for a movie.

reviews.review_title: There are no words to explain how truly stupid it is!
reviews.content: Absolutely nothing in this movie made laugh, actually I felt more like crying when watching it. Yes, It´s really that bad... and what a waste of time!!!!!! Eddie Murphy is so primitive....or maybe I just haven´t got a sense of humor??

What is up with Eddie Murphy?  He's been making a lot of bad choices. Examples include Life, Holy Man, Bowfinger (I'm sorry but that movie wasn't that funny_.  Maybe Eddie needs to figure out what a bad script is because this movie was just that.  The original was plain hilarious non stop.  This sequel is the total opposite with unfunny jokes.  I'll admit that the sick humor was funny but there wasn't that many like the previews claimed there would be.  It was just one of those movies that care about getting more money then caring for how good the movie is. 	I'm very disappointed with Eddie and the director Peter Segal.  Segal was on a great roll with movies (Naked Gun 3, Tommy Boy, and My Fellow Americans) and then he picks the first flop.  And why they put Janet (Made of Plastic) Jackson as the love interest is beyond me.  She can't act worth s***!! 	If you think this movie will be funny by what the previews show, don't go by the previews.  This is not a funny movie!

It is EXTREMELY rare for a sequel to be as good as the original film...and "Nutty Professor 2 : The Klumps" is nowhere NEAR as good as the original. But then again, the first "Nutty" is a modern classic and one of the funniest films of the past ten years. "Nutty 2," judged on it's own merits, is actually a very funny movie, too...movies rarely make me laugh out loud to begin with (and the ones that do usually aren't SUPPOSED to be comedies), so for that in itself "Nutty 2" deserves very high praise.Much criticism has been made about "fart jokes," sexual innuendo and general "sequel-itis"....but why is there such a backlash against crude humor? ALL humor, whether it is at it's most high-brow or stuck squarely in the toilet, has its ups and downs. If it's funny, it's funny, and if it isn't, it isn't. It's that simple. And most of the humor in "Nutty 2" works quite nicely, thankyouverymuch. I never heard ONE criticism about "There's Something About Mary," which took toilet humor to an all-time high and was very funny because of it. Sure, "Nutty 2" doesn't reach the same heights as "Mary," but the criticism it has received for the kind of humor it displays is not only hypocritical, but completely pointless. The movie is funny. Why is that such a problem?Once again, Eddie Murphy's comedic genius is on full display here. Over the years, Murphy has basically coasted through his movies with a sickening lack of enthusiasm and drive...only with the first "Nutty Professor" and "Bowfinger" has he shown audiences the immense talent and ingenuity that was suggested at the beginning of his movie career. In "Nutty 2," he once again plays several characters, each with their own personalities and voices, and the results are amazing. Yes, the make-up helps, but it is Murphy's job to truly pull off these roles, and he does so. Sherman Klump is as charming as ever, and Papa and Mama Klump provide laughs every time they are on screen...but the scene-stealer this time, as in the first "Nutty Professor," is the feisty, sex-starved, and downright scary Granny Klump. Movies like "Nutty 2" generally don't offer much in impressing the Academy come "Oscar" time, but for someone like Eddie Murphy to pull off so many different characters so successfully and hysterically....well, the man deserves MAJOR kudos. An absolutely brilliant performance.Some other familiar faces from the first film emerge here too. Larry Miller and John Ales are back, as the dean and Jason, respectively. I was not expecting much from Janet Jackson....yes, I like her music, but her talents as an actress have always been questionable. I was also wishing Jada Pinkett would show up again. But Miss Jackson gives a surprisingly strong performance, and is quite in her element in this film; acting opposite a powerhouse like Eddie Murphy in itself would be pretty difficult, anyway.Overall, a thumbs up. Not as good as the original, but still a worthy sequel, and VERY funny. Murphy's performances alone are worth the price of admission. And the scene with the hamster is not to be missed!!!

The Klumps are back with the whole family and more funnier than ever.  When they find out about Sherman's discovery, it will have the whole family (The Klumps) going crazy.  A funny movie that will have you out of your seat.  I would watch the first one to laugh more,, but without, you will still be out of your seat.  They say the craziest things in the strangest ways and voices, and knowing Eddie Murphy is doing all of this is even more funny, especially as he plays Grandma.

When I saw this film, I was a little disappointed. The film was rude, and disappointing. This film was, in a way, like "Me Myself and Irene" (2000). A guy with a split personality, fighting for one woman. They were both rude and disappointing. I say Eddie Murphy should forget about a N.P.3I give this movie a 5 out of 10. Rating: This film is okay.

Another how-low-can-you-go Eddie Murphy vehicle, abundant as usual in both vocal and visual jokes related to sex, defecation and smuttiness in general. Definitely a no-see for sophisticated aesthetes of any kind although Janet Jackson herself was placed on top of the dunghill. But it works on its own terms. It IS funny and moves rapidly, too.OK family entertainment if you have the guts to explain your kids what is going on when a full-grown man is being sodomized by a giant mutant hamster.

reviews.review_title: Funniest movie I've seen in a long time
reviews.content: I think a lot of the comments about this movie are unfair. This movie had me laughing so hard I couldn't breathe at times. Same was true of the other folks watching the movie.This movie greatly improves on the 1st one. It refines the rough edges on the characters and make the funny parts even funnier. While this movie has it's crass and rude moments it's definitely a modern classic.I'm not and Eddie Murphy fan, just a fan of good entertainment. Eddie Murphy should have won an Oscar for his performance in this movie. If Dustin Hoffman can win one for "Rain Man" then Eddie should have won for his roles in this movie.

This sequel puts style over substance.  Eddie Murphy plays the various members of the Klump family well, but this obviously proved to be a distraction.  In his zeal he forgot to include a decent story. Unfortunately the story is unconvincing even by "Nutty" standards.

reviews.review_title: Eddie Murphy blazes the screen with comic genius
reviews.content: This is the sort of movie you can just sit back, sit forward and throw up all that popcorn, smarties and pepsi you've just inhaled. Without a doubt, Eddie Murphy's comic charisma and absolute genius ignite throughout the Nutty Professor 2. As a sequel, it tops many of the gags seen in the first installment including a bawdy moment with a hamster. The difference between this film and several other raunchy comedies we've seen in the past 2 years is it doesn't cross the line. It stays within its boundaries and is even more outrageous because of it. There's a reason why only Eddie Murphy can dawn 6 characters in a movie -- he's the only actor out there talented enough to do it.

reviews.review_title: Murphy is amazing, but film suffers from overdose of Klump
reviews.content: When a TV show has a popular supporting character, the networks will attempt to create an entire show based around this character.  These 'spinoffs' are often disappointing, perhaps due to the 'less is more' concept.  In 1996's "The Nutty Professor", the main character's family members stole every scene they were in.  So, the studio decided to make them the focus of the sequel. Unfortunately, I liked the Klump family better as supporting characters. "The Klumps" is funny and enjoyable, but not as much as it could have been.As if the plot is at all important, I'll give a quick synopsis.  Professor Sherman Klump (Eddie Murphy) is on the verge of an amazing scientific discovery--a youth serum.  But his life is complicated by recurring moments when alter-ego Buddy Love (Murphy) takes control of his body.  This is especially damaging to his relationship with lovely Professor Denise Gains (Janet Jackson).  Sherman regains control of his body, but ends up releasing Buddy.  He also begins to suffer some very dangerous side effects.  Buddy wants to sell the formula and make a fortune, and Sherman wants to stop the side effects, marry Denise, and retain the formula.
